comments.content: While this is correct, be aware that in specific situations like Microsoft365 for example, an APP password is part of Basic Authentication, which will be end of life shortly. Most third-party mail applications are starting to support Modern Auth for email clients to allow MFA, such as OAuth
Betty boop is always on top of her game so im trusting this.

discussion.content:
Answer C. Multifactor Authentication is correct
OBJ-2.8: If a user or system has configured their email accounts to require two-factor authentication (2FA) or multifactor authentication, then even if they enter their username and password correctly in the third-party email client they will receive the "Invalid credentials" error message. To overcome this, some email servers will allow the user to create an Application Specific Password to bypass the multifactor authentication requirement, or the user will have to use an email client that supports multifactor authentication.
I think it is because the person is using a third party email client and the original email client uses MFA, so the third party email client doesn't know that.

Obj. 2.8 
When mobile device connectivity cannot be assured, the multifactor method can utilize an email/password combined with facial recognition in order to provide the necessary security level.
so she able to reset the password without MFA, but not able to Login to email client. This is wrong, account lock would be a better answer.

I hate these questions where you kind of just have to assume a lot of backstory and/or details. I find a lot of questions are like this where they play mind games with you. Failed my 1002 because I was too naïve and hoping understanding questions like this will help second time

comments.content: The email client is 3rd party, meaning that the particular app might not have the ability to prompt for MFA and would simply say 'invalid credentials'
Okay, then skip this question in the exam then.

Could be Answer B: Systems will not ALWAYS provide a message stating the account has been locked. I've been locked out of my corporate account before and the only error message I received was "Incorrect Password". Account Lockout messages often don't go to the user for security reasons.

discussion.content:
None of these answers are correct.
Not A - "Full device encryption" - if Ann was able to access her email app then "full device encryption" isn't the problem 
Not B - Account lock - Ann would have received an "account locked" message instead of "invalid credentials" message.
Not D - "Strong password requirements" would not have popped up a message saying "credentials are invalid" during the original login attempt.
Not C - "Multifactor authentication" - Ann was never prompted to provide another piece of authentication (the question doesn't say she was) - instead Ann got "invalid credentials" and was then permitted to change her old password without ever being prompted for another piece of authentication!
Where can one find these OBJ-2.8 explanations

MFA are the following.
Something you know.
Something you are.
Something you have.
Somewhere you are.
MFA isn't always a code. Sometimes it requires you to answer a phone call to push # when prompted by a recording but if you miss the call you may get an error message like invalid credentials.

Only thing is, i never saw an MFA tell you that your credentials are invalid - but rather that it prompts you for a code or id, etc. - usually the credentials are invalid messages appear when the account is locked... i take my test tmrow. wish me luck

comments.content: It's very common nowadays for email accounts to require MFA. They send you a text to your phone number with a code that you need to enter for you to be allowed to access.
Haven't you used G-Mail with MFA? My org has set it to weekly so every Monday, I have to login with my login info + OTP on my phone.

discussion.content: How does an email account require multi-factor authentication? I don't understand.

questions.question_text:
Ann, a user, is attempting to log in to her email service form a third-party email client on her phone. When Ann enters her usual username and password, she receives an error message saying the credentials are invalid. Ann then decides to reset her email password, but after the reset, the new credentials still do not work in the third-party email client.
Which of the following settings or features is responsible for the problems Ann is experiencing?

choices.B: Show the work orders to the customer as proof the issue was resolved.
choices.A: Offer to address the concern since the supervisor is currently unavailable.
choices.D: Call the supervisor on the phone and let the customer talk to the supervisor directly.
choices.C: Tell the customer to return at a later time when the supervisor is available.

questions.question_text: An issue with a user's computer was addressed several times by multiple technicians, but the user has continued to experience the issue. The user calls the help desk and insists on speaking to a supervisor; however, the supervisor is away at lunch. Which of the following should the technician perform FIRST?

A customer keeps receiving the following message: Website blocked due to PUP. The customer asks a technician to resolve the issue immediately. Which of the following should the technician do to help resolve the customer's issue?

choices.D: Enable pop-ups for the website the customer is attempting to visit.
choices.B: Update the antivirus software and run a scan.
choices.C: Advise the customer to not revisit the website.
choices.A: Check the customer's computer for a rogue antivirus.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Update the antivirus software and run a scan - PUP stands for “Potentially Unwanted Program”. It is a message from antimalware software. Malware tries to redirect the user to a malicious website.

comments.content:
https://silicophilic.com/how-to-unblock-website-blocked-due-to-pup/#:~:text=2%20Wrapping%20Up-,Website%20Blocked%20Due%20To%20PUP%20%E2%80%93%20How%20To%20Fix%3F,Malwarebytes%20for%20any%20harmful%20activity.

"One of the primary reasons why you get this error is due to some hidden adware on your computer. This may be in the form of potentially unwanted programs (PUPs), browser extensions, viruses, etc".

"The first thing you should do when you see this message is to run a full virus and malware scan. This is to eliminate any security threats that your computer may have, which may be harmful to your data."

discussion.content: It says 3389 is restricted which is RDP but command line is available. The answer is NOT RDP ... It would be one of the command line options. SSH is the best option.
But vendor is not an employee and it says that 3389 is restricted to employees. So RDP it is for the vendor.

comments.content: Restricted to employees implies the employees can use it. Restricted for Employees implies the employees can't use it.

discussion.content: Venders are not employees and command line are not allowed for non- employees, so RDP is the best answer.
a vendor is not part of the company? so is not an employee too?
Can't be RDP, the port for it is blocked. It would have to be either Telnet or SSH, with SSH being the better option.
SSH secure shell is the correct.
definetly ssh
RDP provides network access for a remote user over an encrypted channel and vendor requires remote access not the employees.

You can start an SSH session in your command prompt by executing ssh user@machine and you will be prompted to enter your password. You can create a Windows Terminal profile that does this on startup by adding the commandline setting to a profile in your settings.May 19, 2020
https://docs.microsoft.com › tutorials
Tutorial: SSH in Windows Terminal - Microsoft Docs

In many, many, MANY questions, assume the user is painfully stupid. Not just ignorant of networking, but legitimately stupid and only kept out of homelessness by their birthright's glass floor.
Sometimes, assume the technician is also painfully inept, like, say, someone who got their certifications simply by memorizing answers to a test rather than first learning the material and then double-checking in case the certifier is known for disingenuously off the wall questions that make no sense the first time around.
CLEARLY we fall in the latter, of course.

discussion.content: They want you to know the malware removal process not some weird malware attack that is unheard of.
If the technician followed the best practice procedures for malware removal in order according to Comptia, the system should be quarantined already and not connected to the Internet...

I get that a damaged NIC would restrict internet access but surely the MOST likely thing you would want is to not be connected to the internet and have it quarantined. But look, I think since the tech is at the remediate stage we have to presume he has already quarantined the system. So he is trying to get updated signatures to hopefully allow the anti malware software to recognize and remove the malware. In order to get that he needs access to the source code from the internet. I guess the malware is a denial of service type maybe because it is designed to deny internet access and prevent getting updates. Since he is already at the remediate stage he has done A and B and C makes no sense. SO only D can be the answer.

it says "to remediate" it has not yet been done
A would make sense
